properties.headline: Flood Advisory issued February 10 at 10:24PM EST until February 11 at 4:15AM EST by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg SC
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Greenville-Spartanburg has issued a

* Flood Advisory for...
Habersham County in northeastern Georgia...
Rabun County in northeastern Georgia...

* Until 415 AM EST Tuesday.

* At 1015 PM EST, Doppler radar and automated rain gauges indicated
persistent light to moderate rainfall since Monday morning
occurring over saturated soils which is resulting in a new round
of stream rises across Rabun and Habersham counties.  Over the
past 6 hours the area has received widespread 1-1.25 inches of
rainfall, with storm-total rainfall of 1.5-2 inches since 7am
Monday morning.

* Additional rainfall of 1-3 inches is possible overnight tonight
through early Tuesday afternoon.  This will exacerbate ongoing
flooding and cause new flooding to develop.  This area may be
upgraded to a Flash Flood Warning if a new round of heavy
rainfall develops overnight. Residents within low-lying areas,
especially adjacent to streams, are encouraged to stay weather
aware and have a way to receive NWS warnings.  Drivers are urged
to obey all barricades and avoid flooded roadways.

* The following streamgauge will exceed Action/Advisory Stage by
11pm:
Soque River at GA 197 near Clarkesville.

CURRENT Stage: 10.53 feet and rising rapidly.
FORECAST: The Soque River will continue to rise to between
12-13 feet 1-3 hours.  Additional rises are possible overnight.

ACTION/ADVISORY Stage: 11.0 feet.
MINOR Flood Stage: 13.0 feet.

IMPACTS: Between 11 and 13 feet, the Soque River will begin
flooding low-lying areas adjacent to the river near Clarkesville,
including Pitts City Park.

* The headwaters of the Tallulah River are also exceeding bankfull
and flooding of adjacent low-lying areas is beginning.  Expect
additional releases downstream within the North Georgia reservoir
system overnight tonight.

* Some locations that may experience flooding include...
Clayton, Clarkesville, Cornelia, Baldwin, Demorest, Mount Airy,
Alto, Mountain City, Tiger and Dillard.
properties.instruction:
Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the
dangers of flooding.

In hilly terrain there are hundreds of low water crossings which are
potentially dangerous in heavy rain. Do not attempt to cross flooded
roads. Turn around, dont drown.
